messages.author: mik_07
messages.content: Hey guys, I just bought an arduino mega, what are some good videoes to watch to have a general understanding of arduino?

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
if you know absolutely nothing about arduino then there's a very long but also very good series on youTube "new arduino tutorials" by paul mcworther. 
For now you could think of the arduino mega as just an arduino uno but with more pins, more ram and more flash. So 99% or arduino uno tutorials still apply. (There are some things that the mega can do or can do better than an uno but afaik nothing the other way around)

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content: and bookmark this https://www.arduino.cc/reference/en/

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content: https://docs.arduino.cc/hardware/mega-2560/

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
here's my personal recommendations â–º https://discord.com/channels/420594746990526466/451155251580633089/1183520688779296768
ðŸ¤“ as per *Pengudash*'s explanation you should be able to try out your MEGA using UNO diagrams... so same with the simulators I suggested *(so there's 0 change you damage your microcontroller board while you're wrapping your head around the concepts involved)* ... 
ðŸ‘‰ the key is to try it as you learn... & keep learning as you go for more & more complicated projects...

messages.author: mik_07
messages.content: Thanks! Will do ðŸ™‚

messages.author: mik_07
messages.content: I see, is it possible to damage the board by putting in code that is wrong?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
shouldn't be an issue unless you're messing about with flashing bootloaders from random HEX files....
ðŸ‘‰ as long as you're using the Arduino IDE then it should be reversible as long as you select the correct board before uploading your code... *(procedures that are covered in Paul's tutorials)* ...

I think you have the 2 things mixed up.
1: Use analog read to measure a potenetiometers position and use that value to set the speed of a motor or set the position of a servo

2. Use a shunt resistor to measure the current flowing trough it

So the potmeter could be used for setting both the motor speed and servo. Or just one of them, doesn't matter

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content:
So. We would use a voltage drop that is detectable by the UNO but not too high. Using ohms law we can calculate that if we want a 0.2V voltage drop that we can measure. 

Resistance:
I = U / R -> R = U / I 
R = 0.2V / 0.8A = 0.25ohms.

Power rating
P = U * I
P = 0.2 * 0.8 = 0.16W

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content:
At a 0.2V voltage drop using the UNO (5 / 1028 = 0.0048V steps of the ADC) so the voltage drop divided by the steps ~5mV -> 0.2/0.0048 = 41.66 steps.
800mA/41.66 = 19mA per step.

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content: You can adjust the values and calculate it yourself to get the resolution you need

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
SD-cards themselves run on 3.3V.
If you have an Arduino Uno, you need an SD-card reader module that has level shifting and 5V->3.3V regulator.
If you have an ESP32 or other similar MCU with 3.3V logic level you need an SD-card reader that has no level shifting.

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
because of the voltage regulator
The "for 5V MCUs" SD-card readers have a voltage regulator that regulates 5V down to 3.3V for the sd-card. If you supply that voltage regulator with less than 4.8V then I don't know what it outputs. Probably not 3.3V so the Sd-card doesn't work.
Because you have an ESP32 you can use a breakout board that doesn't have the useless voltage regulator and supply the sd-card directly with 3.3V

messages.author: ecz_na1
messages.content: Interactive potentiometer game. The tilt switch controls the status of the entire Arduino, it turns on or off the game. The potentiometer decides the servo's position, and the push button is used to score a point and turn off an LED. The game will function as one of 4 LEDs will light up randomly and we need to position the servo using the potentiometer to point towards the LED that is lit up. When it is positioned correctly we will press the push button, it will play a sound and will display 1 representing a point on the LCD. The score will increment by one every time you score a successful point. If the button is pushed when the servo isn't pointing toward the lit-up LED, Incorrect will be displayed on the same LCD, and the score will reset as a sign of losing the game.

messages.author: fakemayham_0.8.4_
messages.content:
1. Check the Port and Board Selection:
Ensure that the correct board is selected in the Arduino IDE:
Go to Tools > Board > Arduino Uno.
Verify that the correct port is selected:
Go to Tools > Port and select the port associated with your Arduino Uno.

2. Check USB Connection:
Ensure the USB cable is properly connected and not damaged.
Try using a different USB port on your computer or a different cable.

3. Restart the Arduino IDE:
Close and reopen the Arduino IDE to ensure that there are no lingering issues.

4. Reboot Your Computer:
Restart your computer to clear any potential conflicts or issues with the USB driver.

5. Disable Other Programs:
Close other programs that might be using the serial port (e.g., other serial monitor applications).

6. Reset the Arduino Board:
Press the reset button on the Arduino Uno before uploading the sketch.

7. Reinstall USB Drivers:
Reinstall the Arduino USB drivers:
Go to Device Manager (Windows), find the Arduino under Ports (COM & LPT), right-click, and select Update Driver or reinstall the driver from the Arduino IDE installation folder.

8. Check Sketch for Issues:
Ensure that your sketch does not have errors. You can enable verbose output in File > Preferences to get more detailed information on the error.

9. Test with a Simple Sketch:
Upload a simple sketch (like the Blink example) to see if the issue is with your current sketch:
Go to File > Examples > 01.Basics > Blink.

10. Reinstall Arduino IDE:
If the issue persists, try reinstalling the Arduino IDE.

messages.author: robherc
messages.content: also always a good troubleshooting idea to unplug everything; reboot your pc; then open ONLY Arduino IDE, plug ONLY the usb into the board; then try to flash again.

messages.author: robherc

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: if you're using Phil's Pico board core then you just set the pins with `SPI.setSCK( usedClockPin );` then simply call `SPI.begin( true );` *(after setting all of your pins to enable hardware SPI; use `SPI1` if you want to set the second channel)*

messages.content: a "port expander" is another option to allow you to have more pins for sensors

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
monochromatic LCDs are fairly rare in the hobby community *(outside of the 16x2 & 20x4 displays powered by Hitachi HD44780 or compatible display driver ICs)*
ðŸ¤” the TWW240128A9-A0 display you linked has a 240x128 resolution... have you considered using an e-Paper display instead?
ðŸ‘‡ they are a bit more expensive than LCDs but have major advantages when it comes to display readability in ambient light & power consumption *(if that is a concern)*...  this 2.13" *Waveshare*  module *(similar products are commonly used as remotely updatable price tags at large chain supermarkets)*  has a resolution of 250X122 ... *(2.9" 296x128 modules are also common)* ...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(btw, these Waveshare ones have a decent amount of documentation & driver support but you need to dig through them & tinker with them since they are not very well organized)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: yes... that's the drawback of e-Paper/e-Ink displays but there are ways around it with partial updates *(if you don't mind the flickering involved in making the display look crisp)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: â˜ï¸ ghosting occurs if you don't flush the screen *(the necessary flickering when you flip any aassigned black pixel to white & white pixel to black before changing it to the color you want)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤” it's an opinion.... I've seen them starting to appear on e-Bikes & it looks very clean & much more premium than monochrome LCD screens imo...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ‘‰ the thing is, since you are making something bespoke & for commercial consumption, I would recommend looking at manufacturers of said displays... so not for the hobby market...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤” I imagine they may even have models that have better refresh rates *(they are getting better if you look at the eBook market)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: shoot... perhaps someone can help...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(btw, support: documentation, driver software, etc ~is the reason why I recommend connecting with manufacturers directly since they will provide all of this to you when you order in bulk)*

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content:
a "4-20mA" current loop is a fairly common industrial control system method of sending data.
with an additional module like shown here <https://www.instructables.com/Interfacing-4-20mA-Current-Loop-Sensors-With-Ardui/> you can "talk" to the sensor using I2C

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: well, the actual resolution you get depends on the sensor... if you are looking for 0.001 psi you may or may not get it ðŸ˜‰

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: you can "hang" up to 127 I2C devices on the bus (as long as they have unique addresses)

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: I2C is meant for short wires (4-20mA allows for long wire runs)

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: yes

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content:
correct, each device has a Clock (SCL) and a data line (SDA)
only one set of pull up resistors is needed, they might be on the modules already

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: SCL and SDA are referred to as a "bus", a set of parallel wires

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: good, then you aren't picturing a big vehicle to move ppl ðŸ™‚

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: similar ig to a 70v speaker system

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: we each have our specialties, haven't played with audio in years...

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: yes, was just illustrating that the real question you need to answer isn't directly related to that sensor but rather "how do I connect an Uno to a 4-20mA current loop"

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content: bear in mind the sensor wants 8v, an Uno can handle max 5v

messages.author: lumanix_zherium
messages.content:
The MPU9250 is a 9-axis IMU. It contains:

3-Axis Gyroscope â€“ Measures rotational velocity around three axes (pitch, roll, yaw).
3-Axis Accelerometer â€“ Measures linear acceleration along three axes (X, Y, Z).
3-Axis Magnetometer (Compass) â€“ Measures the magnetic field strength along three axes, useful for determining orientation with respect to the Earthâ€™s magnetic field.

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
Normal uploading over USB basically works like this:
- Reset the microcontroller
- Bootloader starts
- Hey Bootloader! I want to upload a new program, here is it:
- Bootloader programs the program onto the microcontroller.
- bootloader starts your code

messages.author: robherc
messages.content: Yes, you *can* burn a "barebones" firmware to your 328P over ICSP that does not include any form of arduino bootloader. ... HOWEVER, as per #code-of-conduct we are not allowed to recommend that you do this, and even without that rule, It is very highly recommended against doing that unless you are ***fully certain*** that it's exactly what you want to do, and you're aware of why.

messages.author: robherc
messages.content: Meanwhile, the good news is that if you learn on your own how to ICSP-flash your custom bootloader-free sketch, you ***should*** learn enough in the process to be able to readily re-flash the arduino bootloader back onto your board using the "Burn Bootloader" option in the IDE.

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content:
Ok. You will need a motor driver for the fans to control the speed and a power supply that can handle the load of everything.
An i2c display would take 2 pins. The temperature sensors would likely take 2 pins depending on the type.
The servos need 1 pin each. The fans depend on the method used to drive them.

messages.author: van059349
messages.content: Is there a way to change a default pins set of a module? Lets say i download a library for a certain module, and it tells me to connect to certain pins to arduino (d5, d6 or whatever). Is there a way to change that? Because i dont see it in the code. Is there a hidden part of the code where those pins are set?

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: It depends. For hardware i2c on the Uno R3 for example, you cannot change which pins are used.

messages.author: van059349
messages.content: What is uno r3?

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: An Arduino board.

messages.author: van059349
messages.content: Why does it care wgat pins u use? Arent all d pins the same?

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content:
No, in this specific example, the hardware i2c and spi interfaces on the Atmega328 are only connected to specific pins.
Many other things can use any pins, just these things in particular cannot.
There are microcontrollers that allow you to use any pins you want with the hardware i2c and spi interfaces, the Atmega328 is just not one of them.
You haven't mentioned any of the hardware or libraries you're using, i'm just explaining a situation in which you would not be able to change the pins.

So 500-900mA for normal operation means that on startup it could be several times that amount. That will damage your Arduino and your laptop/PC.

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content:
Either that safety system or the Arduino's safety system (poly fuse) made the Arduino reset/lose connection.
- Just because your household electrical circuit has fuses, you don't go poking it with forks, shorting random stuff and electricuting yourself.

messages.author: sofree._
messages.content: Hey I have a project to make a gait analysis device using arduino and mpu6050 sensors. I need to measure knee angle and also foot angle and foot strike and to validate the device against camera tracking software (SIMI camera) Iâ€™m having issues with I2C connections where it would work for a moment and then it would completely stop working for a long time. I tried adding a whoami loop to the code but it only ran once and I could not test.

messages.author: vilksian
messages.content: You're essentially making body sensors, so are the I2C devices a couple feet away from the controller? If so, I know I2C has limits on how far the signal can go on a bus before it becomes unreliable, and is affected by stray capacitance. IIRC faster data transfer is affected by this capacitance more, so in theory, slower I2C communication should be more reliable with these longer distances.

messages.author: sofree._
messages.content: Whatttttt so if I use slave master connections would that help? I didnâ€™t know about this at all and also if thereâ€™s any sources or material I can read to help me with this? Appreciate your help

messages.author: sofree._
messages.content: They are roughly 40cm away from the sensor placed on the knee and around 80 to the second sensor placed on the shank

messages.author: vilksian
messages.content:
I'm not great at explaining how capacitance affects the signal unfortunately (despite knowing what the *result* can look like), but one thing I can suggest is maybe trying to change the I2C clock speed if the libraries your using allow it. See about slowing it down. 
[This stack exchange post](https://electronics.stackexchange.com/questions/106265/maximum-i2c-bus-length) might help you understand it a bit.

messages.author: vilksian
messages.content: I've actually been trying to solve this problem myself for one of my own projects, and haven't figured out a "pretty" solution yet.

messages.author: sofree._
messages.content: I have 2 weeks to figure it out itâ€™s for my final year project Iâ€™m so cooked

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
I2C uses pull-up resistors to bring the signal lines "back up" to power, and each device on the line can choose to pull the line "low"

If you have stray capacitances, then this can slow down how fast the pull resistors can bring the line back up to a High logic level, which hard-limits your maximum clock rate.

The distance of the pull resistors to the sensor also dictates this. 
Some pre-made modules have the resistors built in, and can sometimes end up with too many pull resistors making the High "too strong" to pull down for each sensor.

You get an R-C time constant when the line is going from low to high, where R is the pull resistors and C is the stray capacitance.
Here's a link to [Hyperphysics](http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/electric/capchg.html) talking about RC time constants and some of the analog world you're going to need to worry about when running wires that long and using I2C

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: If this is a final year project then you should (hopefully) have been exposed to Circuits classes which talk about these things, so time to apply that knowledge of impulse response of a circuit!

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: (or, you can just slow the I2C down until it works 'goodenuf')

messages.author: sofree._
messages.content: I have a previous years code that did this project. Iâ€™m expanding on it by adding foot strike and foot angle measurements. Idk how they were able to get results I think they may have lied

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: To add to this, you should also make sure that the sensor modules that you're using have a proper "tank" or "decoupling" capacitor to be able to pull the I2C lines low when needed, else they need to "wait" for power to travel down the entire line, slowing edges even worse (or in the worst case, completely starving the sensor of power)

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: That's a bold claim to make when you're adding hardware that's so far away and seemingly only now seeing problems

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: Especially when there's reasonable explanations such as this for why you're having problems

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
Wokwi online is good, I've used it and can vouch it's nice for small projects

I've seen people use Tinkercad, but not used it myself. Has a couple extra things like warning you you'll burn out LEDs if you forget a resistor

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: There's `avr-sim`, which can connect to `avr-gdb` if you want to JUST simulate code execution and nothing else, unless you write a testbench type thing that mimics your hardware (this applies only to AVR arduinos like Uno R3 and Megas)

messages.author: vilksian
messages.content: I've used tinkercad's simulator thing, and can confirm it works for simple stuff that one might find in an arduino uno beginner kit. If you want to do stuff outside of that though, you're probably better off looking for alternatives, or just doing physical breadboard stuff.

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: If you want to do circuit simulation, Paul Falstad's `circuitJS` online is an exceptional resource

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: that's more to analog electronics though, things like current measurement and seeing how much current will go through an LED for a given limiting resistor

messages.author: robherc
messages.content: JFETs and some MOSFETs work in "depletion mode" where their default state is "on" ... and pull-up/pull-down resistors to give a regular MOSFET a "default on" state are easy to use as well. ... then the arduino just pulls against the resistor to "switch the MOSFET OFF" once it has the buck converter running stably.

i would use `INPUT_PULLUP` and wire the center pin to ground, one end or the other to the pin

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: it all depends on your motors @Deleted User ... the L298N will drop 2V so if you feed it a 3S lithium power source, you will be giving the motor attached to it anywhere from 6V upto as high as 10.6V depending on the battery cells' state of charge

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(so it will be fine if your motors are rated at 6V-12V DC... but if it's only 3V-6V, you will burn your motors out sooner than later)*

messages.author: Deleted User
messages.content: heres what the seller said

messages.author: Deleted User
messages.content: so i reckon i should probably lower it to 2s then

messages.author: Deleted User
messages.content: what do you think? or is lowering it not necessary

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
although motors can work above their rated voltages doing so will burn out their coils sooner than later, shortening its operational life...
ðŸ‘‰ so using a 2S lithium battery pack provides from 5.5V to 8.4V, the motor driver's drop will leave you with around 3.5V to 6.4V for your motors which would work fine *(since lithium cells don't stay at their peak/full voltages for very long)*.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤“ naturally, if you want more consistent performance from your motors *(rather than dependent on the battery's state of charge)* ... you could always use your 3S or 2S pack & use a buck boost converter to keep it at a constant voltage *(like 5.5V so you're not stressing your motors too much)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: âš ï¸ naturally, your converter should be able to handle your expected load & then some as a safety margin... so 4 motors x 350mA each(max) x 20% safety margin == 1.68A *(or a `2A buck boost converter`)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: it's due to the L298N driver's 2V voltage drop @Deleted User so they'll need to feed it more voltage so that more voltage reaches the motors or use a different motor driver

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
ðŸ¤“ for more information about what's available for hobbyists & tinkerers, check out Bill's article *(& video)*  on the subject...
ðŸ“š https://dronebotworkshop.com/dc-motor-drivers/

What kind of board is it? You might have bricked it and will have to program it with an ICSP programmer.

messages.author: kaviaar
messages.content: hi, i'm new to arduino, i was triyng to buy a infrared sensor to "copy" values from a remote, but instead i bought a obstacle avoidance module , is it possible to use this as an normal infrared?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
the IR proximity sensor module is designed to use the IR transmitter to send a pulse that goes off ahead of it until it is reflected by an object that is close enough back to the IR receiver....
ðŸ‘‰ the receiver's reading is passed to a comparator that signals `HIGH` when it detects a reflected pulse based on the sensitivity set by the onboard potentiometer *(the blue box)*...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ˜… so short answer is "no".... *(at least not without major surgery on the module)*

messages.author: mevrouwbaktaart

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: this is why I said *"you can never tell"*  ... there are ways to verify things... remember that you didn't download those drivers from somewhere ... they came with Arduino IDE's installer *(which you downloaded from Arduino's official website)*... so the likelihood of a 3rd party injecting their malware is fairly small

arvincible
messages.content: okay I am not sure if this counts as hardware or coding problem but I am trying to make a esp32 internet radio and i realise that my esp32 is overheating even without anything connected to it. I tested a plain blinking code and it doesnt overheat so I think theres something in my code overheating my esp32. Can anyone help?

messages.author: arvincible
arvincible
m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: No code should cause the ESP32 to overheat.

messages.author: arvincible
messages.content: Not kidding mate, I thought it was because I was using Wifi so i uploaded another code which uses Wifi and esp32 cooled down using that code. Troubleshooting led me to conclude the code I sent is overheating my esp32

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: The voltage regulator was probably damaged and can no longer provide the current needed for WiFi without issues. It's not the code, it's the current draw.

messages.author: arvincible
messages.content: but in both tests i did the esp32 has nothing connected to the pins, it is just running while connected to my computer via usb

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content:
The ESP32 microcontroller on the dev board is drawing current from the voltage regulator on the board that supplies it's power. It draws a lot of current when using WiFi.
This regulator is also connected to the 3.3v pin which you previously had connected to the audio amplifier which was probably drawing enough current in combination with the ESP32 to damage the regulator or something else on the board.

messages.author: arvincible
messages.content: ah shit man this board is brand newðŸ˜­  Alright I will buy another board. Thank you for the time I will connect the audio amp to 5v or external power source next time

messages.author: arvincible
messages.content: So I tried with the 5v pin and external power supply and 2 different esps and I still get the ssme result where the code just heats up the esp32, I ran other codes that have wifi involved and it doesnt get hot

messages.author: arvincible
messages.content: okay I think i solved it, after hours and different esps and power supplies. I just changed the pin numbers of DOUT, BCLK, LRC and the heating problem stopped... I dont know how or why that worked but if anyone has an explaination pls go ahead

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: Doesn't make sense to me. Unless it's just typical getting warm and not really overheating.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content:
> my problem is that the arduino is getting power witouth connecting the barrel jack
I have seen multiple cases of parasitic powering due to a voltage being present on the microcontroller's I/O pins, which in turn have a I/O protection diode connected between them and e.g. 5V. And hence, voltage can leak in to the voltage net of the microcontroller's supply voltage.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: Specifically as seen in <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2yFh7Vv0Paw>

This sounds like you haven't gotten the drivers installed right for re-flashing the 16u2 chip; Are you 100% sure that the usb-serial bridge chip on your Uno is a 16u2 and not an 8u2?

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
Have you been able to try another OS?
I'm fairly sure there's an ArduinoIDE install for most Linux distros, which can also be "tried" on a thumbdrive in LiveCD mode

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: Plonk something like that on a thumbstick, install the Arduino IDE, and see if you can get it to recognize the Arduino

messages.author: _wee_gee_

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: Reinstalling windows is also always an option

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: if the board is recognized by any computers at all, then the board is probably OK; it's probably a driver or OS issue on the ones that don't recognize it

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
Now, I'm making a lot of assumptions here:
-That these are genuine Arduino Uno R3s (not clones!)
-That the computers being used are Windows computers
-that the device enumeration error is coming up for the Arduinos and not some other random device

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: It's an `snprintf` call with a format spec for 2-digit numbers with leading zeros

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: It lets you "print" things to a string first, *then* output them to whatever

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: Technically you could also write the format spec so that the hours digit has a leading space, a `' '` instead of a `'0'`

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: does it still blink if you throw away the IR remote far away so the signals don't reach?

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: it might be a power reset problem the moment the motor is switched on.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: why, an Arduino only has like 5V or 3.3V of output voltage capability?

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: it's not about the input power supply range, it's about the drive capability of the chip

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: e.g., this chip can **sink** 16mA max, but only source 0.4mA.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: so, an inverted LED setup where, the output of the logic gate goes to the negative side of the LED, with the other side of the LED being connected to e.g. +5V throug a 1 kohm resistor, works better, because it can sink currrent better than it can source

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content:
go to #bot-commands and type !pullup
that description talks about Arduino but it applies to logic gates as well
you can't leave a gate input "floating", it will act like an antenna, which is what I see in your video

messages.author: anonengineering

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: if your buttons connect the input of the logic gate to +5V when pressed, then you need a pull-down resistor on the input gate to prevent the floating (undefined) input voltage when the button is **not** pressed

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: e.g., 10 kOhm between each logic gate input and GND.

messages.content: calder - have you read the docs?

messages.author: ja_pinkerton
messages.content: because it looks kinda easy.    But I suspect your question is "how do I know what to write where?   How do I know where to read what I wrote?"

messages.author: ja_pinkerton
messages.content: And I think the answer is "flash memory isn't a file system."     You want to allocate the addresses by hand or at least at compile time.  So you know that address 0 is always one thing, and address 128 is some other thing, and address 132 is a third thing

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content:
what do you see?
The HC-05 Bluetooth module uses blinking LED patterns to indicate its status. Rapid flashing (around 2 Hz) indicates communication mode, not connected. Two rapid flashes followed by a longer pause signify communication mode, connected. A slow, steady flash (on for 2 seconds, off for 2 seconds) indicates the module is in AT mode, ready for configuration commands.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: not really... the error indicates that the UNO was not detected *(IDE couldn't communicate with the board)* ... whereas having the IDE set to communicate on COM3 is an option that is user selectable *(it's possible that at one point the UNO was indeed at COM3 but it isn't anymore)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ‘‰ I recommend checking your `Device Manager â†’ Ports` to see if the Arduino is listed there & at which port... *(you can unplug & reconnect the UNO to verify the correct port ~it should disappear when unplugged & reappear when reconnected)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: common occurrance when you overheat the pads during soldering... too much heat will make them delaminate from the fiberboard surface

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
okay. so that indicates that your UNO isn't responding when the IDE attempts to communicate with it during programming...
ðŸ‘‰ make sure there's nothing connected to pins 0 & 1 of the UNO board... these pins are used for communications with the IDE & PC...
ðŸ‘‰ if there's nothing connected to those pins, try hitting the [`RESET`] button twice *(to force the UNO into "bootloader" mode)*   just before hitting the button on the IDE to upload your code ...

messages.author: diamonddback
messages.content:
When evaluating safety precautions, isolated exceptions do not define best practices.

Consider this scenario: Someone asks, "Should I use a parachute when jumping from a plane at 30,000 feet?"

A flawed response would be: "Technically, there was one person who jumped without a parachute and survived for almost four minutes, so you should be fine without one."

This reasoning ignores the overwhelming evidence supporting parachute use for survival. An outlier event should not override established safety principles.

messages.author: ostenjoyer3103
messages.content: Guys when im done with arduino for the day, can I just unplug the arduino and other stuff with all the code still on there or do i have to first upload a blank sketch then unplug it?

messages.author: akumasaru
messages.content: Unplugging the Arduino just gives you power loss.  The code you have on there is not lost due to power loss.  So when you turn it on, it should still have your most current project code on it, and run those functions.  Unless something happened to the device or the reset button was pushed, etc.  It won't change code until you connect it to the IDE again and upload new/older code to the device.

messages.author: ostenjoyer3103
messages.content: Im not worried about it wiping the code, im just asking can i damage the board by unplugging it while running a code and powering an led?

messages.author: akumasaru
messages.content: no

I am having trouble using 4 slaves on my arduino mega.
I made a bus for clock, MISO, MOSI and Reset pin using the SPI pins (just learned about that)
But now I dont now what pins I am supposed to use for my Save Select
Online I find that I only have pin 53 as slave select, but if I have multiple slave, how do I use it?

For now, I connected my slaves on pins 45 to 48 and weirdly, only two of my four slaves are working correctly

messages.author: browniezoulou
messages.content: I guess that's a hardware problem, but maybe I am coding something bad. What should I check?

messages.author: browniezoulou
messages.content: Maybe I am supposed to use pwm pins? But then again, I only have three

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
> But now I dont now what pins I am supposed to use for my Save Select
If you're doing SPI, usually each individual slave has it's own separate SS pin.
You'd use any other general digital pin. Doesn't need to be PWM or anything fancy, just any pin that can be used as a digital pin.
Also, make sure you don't have multiple slave devices selected at once.

> I guess that's a hardware problem, but maybe I am coding something bad. What should I check?
Try each device individually with all others disconnected from the bus, with small snippets of example code that tests ONE slave device. If they work individually, then it's probably something with your code when running them all at the same time, likely selecting multiple devices at once.

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
`digitalWrite` is about as fast as a few thousand times per second minimum (there's a little overhead when doing `digitalWrite` instead of directly manipulating the port registers) so that's probably not the issue

You're using a lot of `#define`d constants; I'd suggest using
-`enum`s for the different states (so you just declare them all at once)
-`const int`s for anything that doesn't change during program execution (sidesteps the problem of `#define`s being just fancy find-and-replace that can have weird bugs if you're not used to looking for them)


On the actual code itself, I think `distance` not being `volatile` is probably causing one of your issues.
Since `distance` is being updated by `ping`, which I assume is being called via a timer interrupt somewhere within the `NewPing` library, you need to tell the compiler "always re-load this value from it's location in memory; never assume it's not changed between the last time you read it"

I still don't see how you're observing that the loop is too slow. 
State exactly what you SEE (or observe), and what you EXPECT to see, and how they're different

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: `pulseIn` can also take a time-out as a parameter

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content: so you could use the typical ultrasonic sensor code but with a strict timeout that's not a full second (which is the default for `pulseIn`)

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
> I don't know how to tell the compiler distance is volatile
it's standard C++, a google search should point you in the right direction too, but it's just `volatile int distance = -1;`; just a different kind of variable
>  i expected #define to be more performant than const int
the compiler's smarter than that. `const int` also lets the compiler check that you didn't make a mistake like using a `const unsigned int` where you wanted a `const int`
`const int` also makes it so you don't get weird order-of-operations thing happen like this:
```ino
#define MY_CONSTANT 6+7
void setup(){
  Serial.println(MY_CONSTANT*3);
}
```
this doesn't necessaily print `(6+7)*3`, it might print `6+(7*3)`
tl;dr the compiler is smart enough to strip out things like that and replace them with their equivalents.

If you don't believe me, [Compiler Explorer](https://godbolt.org/) has a mode to compile code for Arduino boards etc. so you can see the assembly has no difference between `const`s and `#define`s

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
ISRs are "function that gets immediately called when an interrupt happens, pausing whatever else was happening at the time"; it's an Interrupt Service Routine

If however, an interrupt interrupts an ISR, then there's high chance for issues to arise, especially if you "pause" the ISR to... go do the ISR
eventually something will do unpredictable things

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
-> you want to finish the ISR asap so that 
-the code being interrupted doesn't notice
-another interrupt won't happen while the ISR is still not done

messages.author: _wee_gee_
messages.content:
whenever you use an Arduino (at least an Uno) with the Arduino IDE, you have interrupts going "in the background" all the time; the interrupt that updates `millis` for you. 
It's so fast though that it barely registers unless you're doing microsecond-accurate work

messages.author: tuulikauri

messages.author: tuulikauri
messages.content: If its the last two, a piece of masking tape to hold your prototype together can go a long way ðŸ˜„

messages.author: tuulikauri
messages.content: If its actually that the wire is very tiny and loose, you can strip the insulation off until you have about 1.5 cm bare wire, fold the end on itself and twist it together so its one thicker piece of bare wire. If you do that with 22 AWG wire though, it will be too thick to go in the breadboard.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤” perhaps consider using a *Pro Micro*  or *RP2040*  based board *(like the `Arduino NANO RP2040 Connect`)*  which are both popular choices for custom HID keyboards & controllers...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *( ðŸ¤· you'll need to do a bit of digging regarding that... but I haven't heard as many issues with the Pro Micro as compared to the Leonardo for HID applications)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: it's a great board but it's "too new" for my taste... vs other older boards which are more widely supported

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: you could buy some boards with presoldered headers

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: yup... they did though I haven't seen them on sale lately...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: might be worth investing in a good soldering iron & learning a very useful skill for tinkering

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: roughly $30ish for a *Pinecil V2 (or V1)*  but that doesn't come with a power supply *(you'll need around 65W or better)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(they can be that high for branded smart irons like `Hakko` or `Weller`)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *the key is that they need proper internal PID temperature control*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: also understand that there is a massive size difference between an `Arduino R4 Minima` vs other boards *(like the Pro Micro, NANO, & the stamp-sized boards that are gaining popularity)* ... which makes the smaller form factor of other boards more attractive for portable HID controllers

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: again, depends on what you're actually building ðŸ˜‰

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: one big advantage of larger boards are their available GPIO pins ðŸ¤“ but that can be mitigated by shift registers & IÂ²C port expanders

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: or course...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
ðŸ‘‰ HID is a standard for computer peripherals...
ðŸ‘‰ Arduino is an ecosystem *(board + IDE + libraries)*  that allow you to create microcontroller projects relatively easily...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤“ so any microcontroller board that is "HID compliant" can be made into an HID peripheral by using the appropriate libraries that allow it to communicate with the computer it's attached to via USB...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(aka the "firmware")*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: then unless you're simply copying an existing HID controller project, then building a car SIM controller from scratch is fairly intermediate to advanced

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(electronics + programming -wise)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: haven't really looked into `Hoodloader2` myself but as it will be messing/reprogramming the onboard chip to force an UNO into HID compliance, I definitely wouldn't recommend it... *(specially since there are plenty of comparatively low cost out of the box HID compliant boards out there)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ‘‰ as a beginner, I'd recommend following the guide to the letter *(with the board they specifically used)* ... then you'll hope it's a good guide *(at least one who's not faking their results; if it's a guide that tells you to use `Hoodloader2` then I'd look for a different one)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: again. I don't condone this practice *(relying on generative AI or forcing an UNO to a task it wasn't meant for)*  so if that's the path you wish to go with... all I can say is good luck with your project...

messages.author: toph2814

messages.content: ArduinoISP is code you would put on a WORKING arduino to turn it into a programmer. If you dont have any working arduinos right now, dont worry about it. ðŸ™‚

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: Sounds like it just reset it and did not run the bootloader. Arduino says to hold down the reset button on a Leonardo, click the upload button and do not realease it until you see "Uploading...". Maybe Arduino used different bootloaders for these two and your boards have the wrong one. Or the bootloader has been corrupted, or the firmware on the board is causing a problem. Not sure.

messages.author: jasoso
messages.content: Hey! I got a quick question. So with a 5000-10000mah and I think a tp4056. Can I use the tp4056 to power my rpi 3b with the battery connected? And can I use it while charging? Or should I just use a powerbank module?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
you'll definitely need a "`boost converter`" in addition to the TP4056 lithium battery charging module to bring the voltage to a constant 5V *(which is what the RPi wants)* ...
â˜ï¸ and yes, with the TP4056 you can charge while using....
ðŸ¤“ of course, you'd be better off with a powerbank module *(since it already has both the charging + cell balancing circuit & voltage regulation to provide a 5V output)* ... 
 ... âš ï¸ however you need to make sure that the powerbank module can supply __at least 2A__ of power out of its USB-A port *(this should be good as long as you don't plug too many power hungry devices on your RPi's USB ports)* ... naturally 3A would be best so there's little to no chance of undervoltage warnings âš¡...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤“ ðŸ‘‰ note that if you're going the "`5v boost converter`" route, make sure it can supply 3A as well ðŸ˜‰

messages.content: ðŸ¤” got a pic?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
a switch? 
ðŸ¤” depends on what you're turning "off" ... 
ðŸ‘‰ since you'll be running an operating system on your RPi3, you should hook up a momentary pushbutton to one of its GPIO pin that will trigger your shutdown routine *(otherwise you run the risk of currupting your Linux filesystem)*...
ðŸ‘‰ if you also want to be able to turn off power to the RPi3 to preserve battery power, you can place it between the TP4056 & the boost converter *(you can turn off just the `+` with a SPST toggle switch or both `+` & `-` with a SPDT one)*...
âš ï¸ just don't place it after the boost converter .... because those circuits typically don't like it when you power it up with no load *(hence the dummy load resistor I suggested earlier)* ...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: all GPIO pins can be used... but know that pins 0 & 1 are tied to RX & TX for UART *(the USB serial connection to your PC & Arduino's IDE)*  respectively @Dylan ....

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: â˜ï¸ so if you do use those pins, you can't use the Serial Monitor or use `Serial` for input & output...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(using them also affects programming/uploading a new sketch/code to the board)*

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: â˜ï¸ definitely reduces the hassle of having to disconnect anything on pins 0 & 1 every time you want to update the UNO's code...

messages.author: toph2814

HID compliance is the path of least compliance since you just plug your device into a USB port & it will be recognized accordingly...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
no... 
ðŸ¤“ take note that voltage is not a suggestion... for most components, they are made to work at that specific voltage *(think of a 110V appliance used in a country with 220V mains)* ...
ðŸ‘‰ LEDs typically can be over driven *(using a higher voltage on them than they're rated for)*  and although it will often allow the LEDs to get brighter, their life will be shortened since they will burn out sooner than later.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤“ to determine how much current your project requires, you look at each component's datasheet *(microcontroller, LEDs, sensors, motors, etc)*  to see what current they will need... add all of them together... to get the total current requirement...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
ðŸ‘‰ so just to clarify, the key is the amount of current each LED will pull... for standard 5mm LEDs, that's usually upto 20mA... for super bright "cob"-type LEDs, they typically range for 1W to 5W *(so 200mA to as high as 1A)* ... so 15 of them would mean you'd multiply the current requirements...
â˜ï¸ this will then dictate the amount of power your power supply needs to provide at 5V... so for 15x 1W LEDs == 3A *(or a 15W power supply with 5V output)*  minimum *(a 30W power supply will work fine, just means it has a big enough "reservoir" to handle more current than is needed)*...
ðŸ˜„ hope this clears things up...

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content:
in regards to these three pads you can use your multimeter to measure:
* red lead in the middle pad, black lead on ground of the arduino (e.g. USB connector shield): gives you the supply voltage of the PCA9.. chip. should be +5V. If it's 0 then the PCA chip has no power. then the middle pad should be connected to the lower 5V pad with a blob of solder.
* red lead on the bottom pad, black lead on ground of the arduino (e.g. USB connector shield): gives you the 5V voltage on the board. should be +5V.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: if it has power, then check continuity between the SCL <--> SCL and SDA <--> SDA connection. (arduino <-> servo board).

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content:
if the servo board has power and the i2c lines are connected properly, it **should** be showing up on the I2c scanner..
Should also be a direct connection between the Arduino's GND pin and the servo shield's GND pin

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content:
Well, depending on your particular ESP32, the onboard regulator might be able to convert the voltage of a single 18650 lithium ion cell to the desired 3.3V. For that the droupout voltage needs to be very low.

What regulator does your ESP32 use? Google the datasheet of it and find the dropout voltage to depermine whether it can be used so easily.

If not, there are still many other solutions.

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content: Or just use a powerbank

messages.author: klevi_
messages.content: There are quite small powerbanks. They are handy as you don't risk damaging your electronics

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content:
the DFRobot core uses this config
```
firebeetle8266.name=DFRobot FireBeetle-ESP8266

firebeetle8266.upload.tool=esptool
firebeetle8266.upload.speed=460800
firebeetle8266.upload.resetmethod=nodemcu
firebeetle8266.upload.maximum_size=1044464
firebeetle8266.upload.maximum_data_size=81920
firebeetle8266.upload.wait_for_upload_port=true
firebeetle8266.serial.disableDTR=false
firebeetle8266.serial.disableRTS=false

firebeetle8266.build.mcu=esp8266
firebeetle8266.build.f_cpu=80000000L
firebeetle8266.build.board=FireBeetle-ESP8266
firebeetle8266.build.core=esp8266
firebeetle8266.build.variant=firebeetle8266
firebeetle8266.build.flash_mode=dio
firebeetle8266.build.flash_size=4M
firebeetle8266.build.flash_freq=40
firebeetle8266.build.debug_port=
firebeetle8266.build.debug_level=

firebeetle8266.menu.CpuFrequency.80=80 MHz
firebeetle8266.menu.CpuFrequency.80.build.f_cpu=80000000L
firebeetle8266.menu.CpuFrequency.160=160 MHz
firebeetle8266.menu.CpuFrequency.160.build.f_cpu=160000000L

firebeetle8266.menu.UploadSpeed.921600=921600


firebeetle8266.menu.FlashSize.4M3M=4M (3M SPIFFS)
firebeetle8266.menu.FlashSize.4M1M=4M (1M SPIFFS)
```

messages.author: anonengineering
messages.content:
to test your hardware you don't even need an Uno
each resistor has one end on the 7 seg, the other end goes to a pin
if COM goes to ground you can connect a jumper from 5v to the end on each resistor that goes to a pin (disconnect from Uno first)

messages.author: aaravthagoat
messages.content: For arduino, I recommend using the smallest one. An ESP32 has WAYY more processing power, and itâ€™s small. If you want to incorporate simple AI, I think an Esp32 is the best choice. (Esp32 is also less beginner friendly)

messages.author: aaravthagoat

messages.author: elaiire
messages.content: I was wondering if a microcontroller different than an arduino? Or are they just the same?

messages.author: aaravthagoat
messages.content: There are many different types of microcontrollers .  An microcontroller is basically a chip you can program. Arduino is the basically most popular microcontroller right now

messages.author: elaiire
messages.content: Thank youu!

messages.author: aaravthagoat
messages.content: STM 30, ESP8266, Raspberry Pi Pico, and arduino Nano are examples of some microcontrollers

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
fyi/clarification @elaiire, these are just some of the popular `microcontrollers` and the (development boards) you will typically find them in: 
ðŸ‘‰ `STM32`, `ESP8266`(NodeMCU)  | `ESP32` (many variants on many DevKits), `RP2040`(RPi Pico) | `RP2350`(RPi Pico 2), `ATmega328P`(UNO, NANO)  | `ATmega2560`(MEGA) ... 
â˜ï¸ the microcontroller is effectively the processor IC that serves as the brains of the microcontroller development board which are custom PCBs that contain all the necessary support electronics to make the microcontroller function & allow you to make connections to the IC to send & receive signals to do different tasks...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ¤“ meanwhile "`Arduino`" is the company & the workflow infrastructure they've built *(Arduino IDE & core libraries)*  that allows us to program these microcontrollers relatively easier than before...

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(oh, they've also provided the schematics for their microcontroller boards so everyone can effectively build their own... which is why we have so many knockoffs & clones, even branded clones out there for us to choose from)*

messages.author: elaiire
messages.content: Thank youu!

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
That chip is the USB<->UART converter.
Without it, communication with the Serial Monitor on the PC, and uploading new programs to the arduino won't work.

messages.author: tahagamer11
messages.content: ah ok thanks

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content:
But the arduino itself can still work if only that chip is broken.
You will need a second arduino or a USB-serial converter to upload new programs to the half-broken arduino or use the serial monitor with the half-broken arduino.

messages.author: penpengu
messages.content: You could use that half-broken arduino in a permanent installation

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: The Adafruit one uses a full framebuffer for the display (128 x 64 / 8 bytes = 1024 bytes)

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: But the u8g2 can do only a single page buffer of 128 byte

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: so your sketch can have more logic and use more RAM if you use u8g2.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: Usually the SH1106 display has a "RESET" pin which cleanly resets the display for each run

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: your display doesn't have that, so if it ever gets stuck in a weird state, you have to powercycle it.

please try this
```ini
[env:upesy_wroom]
platform = espressif32
board = upesy_wroom
framework = arduino
upload_port = COM5
monitor_speed = 115200
lib_deps = 
    bodmer/TFT_eSPI@^2.5.43
build_flags = 
    -D USER_SETUP_LOADED
    -D ILI9341_DRIVER
    -D TFT_BL=21
    -D TFT_CS=15
    -D TFT_RST=-1
    -D TFT_DC=2
```

messages.author: diamonddback
messages.content:
That was indeed my intention. And for your information, I understand how frustrating it can be to create the diagram at this stage. We've all been there. However, this experience should serve as a reminder to document your progress as you go.

For any project, regardless of its size, even if you're just sketching on a piece of paper with crayons and taking a picture to save in the project folder, keeping a running document is crucial. 

If you don't want to use EDA software, common tools include MS Paint, GIMP, Inkscape, Draw.io, or any PowerPoint/slide software.

Here's a suggested workflow: when starting a project, before pulling out a breadboard, create a quick draft using PowerPoint (for example). Insert an image of a breadboard, add an image of the ESP, and wire it up as you envision. Follow this draft as you work. If you discover, for instance, that pin 16 can't be used because it's input-only, first update your diagram by removing the "wire" and reconnecting it to a new pin, such as pin 34. Then replicate the changes on the actual breadboard.

By working this way, you'll always have an up-to-date wiring diagram that evolves with your project. When dealing with complex sections like motor drivers and other components, break each part into its own slide to avoid clutter. For instance, the right side of the motor driver could be on slide 12, while the left side continues on slide 13, and so on.

I also use software to maintain not only wiring diagrams but also all code revisions, ensuring everything stays organized and accessible.

If you do this any time you need help you have everything at hand, what wiring was working yesterday? here you go.. what wiring you have NOW? here you go. is it up to date? as of 5 minutes ago, yes.

messages.content: I am trying to use a arduino uno to add some buttons to my logitech g923 steeringwheel. I entered code into it using simhub but I need a way to flip the series imput into a keypress. I know I can get a Leonardo but preferably I use this Arduino.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content:
understand that to be plug & play with most modern operating systems *(Windows, Linux, Android, MacOS, iOs)*  the USB device has to be `HID`-compliant *(`H`uman `I`nterface `D`evice ~a standard)* ...
ðŸ¤“ unlike a *Leonardo (or other HID compliant microcontroller development boards like the Pro Micro, RP2040-based ones, & ESP32s)*, an *Arduino UNO*  is not... so you'll need software running on the operating system side to take the serial information from it to simulate keystrokes.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: ðŸ˜“ although there are ways to force an *UNO*  into HID compliance, making a mistake during the process *(which from what I've read doesn't always work on all clones or knockoffs out there)*  will render your *UNO*  board useless... which is why I *(& many helpers in this server)*  do not recommend it.

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: *(... specially since alternative boards are a lot cheaper & much more compact)*

messages.author: nick0470
messages.content: So I should just give up and go for a leonardo?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: or one of the many more capable HID compliant options...

messages.author: nick0470
messages.content: I just need it to control 10 buttons some LEDs and RGB matrix, I was gonna get 2 pro minis to control the matrix. Are the pro minis overkill?

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: a single `Pro Mini` has more than enough pins to control both a 10 button matrix as well as RGB LEDs *(assuming they're addressable LEDs)*

messages.author: nick0470
messages.content: None of them are RGB and I might need to use a header per led because I want it to act like a rpm gauge.

messages.author: nick0470
messages.content: And I will have to RGB matrix

messages.author: toph2814
messages.content: needless to say I'm lost as you've seemingly just contradicted yourself

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content:
If you have wiring between the two hardware serial ports, uploads will fail.
The same UART connections are used for communication with the computer.
If you want to retain the ability to program the MCU, you could use the SoftwareSerial library.

messages.author: .pseud0

messages.author: .pseud0

messages.author: .pseud0

messages.author: diamonddback
messages.content: There is no physical "pin 16" on the hardware. To simplify coding for new users, we abstract the hardware level to a value we refer to as "16," which is then displayed on the board. This allows users to easily identify and control what they perceive as "pin 16." Occasionally, board manufacturers may omit or mislabel this abstraction, leading to control of an unintended pin. To address this, I bypassed the standard library and directly manipulated the underlying hardware to activate the intended pin, which is labeled as "16."

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: how to flash an esp32 without using the usb?

messages.author: m_a_v_e_r_i_c_k
messages.content: Over the air (OTA) using WiFi.

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: cool, ill look into it

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: do you know about a solution using wires?

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: If you can get a UART connection to the Boot UART (aka TXD0 RXD0) and a way to reset the chip ito bootloader (usually via EN and IO0), then you can flash via UART.

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: In fact, the USB port is just a USB to UART converter. The actual flashing goes via UART.

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: OTA seems a bit risky imo

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: i dont trust myself enough to always include the OTA example in the new code im flashing

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: There are fallbacks in place if a new OTAA update fails to boot and a factory partition with a known good firmware.

messages.author: faxmachinelover
messages.content: no need for buttons?

messages.author: .pseud0
messages.content: No.

messages.author: .pseud0
